What I love most about this game is probably the one thing that puts off a huge chunk of other people:
The absence of something out there trying to kill you, except for the lack of oxygen/water/food. There is no predator hunting you, no aliens shooting at your back. It's just you versus the atmosphere. And it's on you to change that as well.
So you can REALLY focus on creating a lush, beautiful planet out of a dead wasteland, all while exploring cool landscapes, shipwrecks and hidden lore. 
You build base(s) and get your automation started for more resources to build more and better things, that will transform this dull marsian planet into a living, breathing home. 

For me this game is the perfect balance of exploration and "strategy" on how you spend your resources. I adore that this game has other priorities that so many others from this "branch" have. Nothing jumpscares you or makes you stressed out and fear for your life - but places can still be scary and uncomfortable to navigate through, keeping you on your toes for a hot minute (also thanks to the eerie soundtrack), as fall damage or drowning/suffocating/burning/starving still can kill you. 

Overall a great game to relax and tinker when you're not the kind of person who destresses with "stressful" games. It's just so.. satisfying visiting a faraway place after a long time and the once sad, sandy dunes are now green and lush. It's a good kind of dopamine.

Playing the 1.0 update of Planet Crafter has been fun so far— now that I'm approaching the end and progression feels fairly repetitive and drawn out, I feel like I've formulated my thoughts enough to share them in a review.

Planet Crafter is a game with big ideas! You're taking an entire map that's so barren and orange/red it hurt my eyes at times, and turning it into something lush and honestly pretty striking at times! It's very fun and rewarding to watch the map transform. The gameplay(and indeed, much of the game design itself) borrows from Subnautica; you explore, you gather resources, you build your base, you make the world your own. Instead of finding the unique flora and fauna like in Subnautica, you get to put it there yourself!

Many of my issues with this game, and why I will not be finishing it despite being a stone's throw away from the finish line and ending, stem from technical issues and an apparent lack of polish that I originally thought was attributed to the early-access state of the game. Now that we're at a full release, I feel that the game is far too unstable. Hitches, freezes, and an apparent memory leak that caused my entire computer to lock up on multiple occasions made playing the game more stressful than rewarding or fun, because I was always worried about saving as early and often as possible to protect my progress(which is largely just based on waiting real-world time for your terrformation values to tick up) from the inevitable crashes.

The map is full of holes. I found a gap in the geometry within a 15-second walk from the spawn point that allowed me to clip under the rocks. The game evidently makes a lot of concessions to maintain performance; one of these concessions is very aggressive LOD and occlusion culling of basically everything. Map geometry, player-placed buildings, even the plants that you grow will very obviously pop in and out of existence as you are moving to and fro. The lay of the land is hard to get a grasp on because of how drastically the environment changes as you travel; something I thought was just a bare hill that would allow me to access another part of the map is actually blocked by a huge cliff that simply popped into existence when I got close enough. It's jarring, confusing, and immersion-breaking. Another comparison to Subnautica is hardly fair here; those guys had the advantage of an ever-present underwater fog to hide what they were doing in the distance, but they also had the environments and objects fade in and out rather than simply appearing and disappearing. I don't want to make assumptions, but it feels very much like higher-quality assets and systems were added onto the very shaky foundation built by the team working on this game when they were much more amateur as developers. One example of this I feel is the lack of a proper day-night cycle. The skybox is eternally static, and "night" is signified by the game cranking down the exposure without changing how anything is lit. It's strange and doesn't feel like something that should have passed any kind of a quality check for the 1.0 release, which is a statement that I unfortunately feels like applies to many things about this game.

I hope that some day I can return to this game and properly finish it without the pains of the current version. If you love survival-craft games, this is probably still worth a try. If you love having a smooth and well-polished experience, this game is not for you.

I'm a huge sucker for survival and base building games, and the idea of throwing terraforming into the mix really appealed to me. When faced with the brain-dead simplicity of the early game, however, I just couldn't bring myself to continue and see whether the changes to the planet were sweet enough to make up for my utter boredom and disappointment.

Resource gathering amounted to "pick up minerals that are scattered around in a roughly even distribution." No deposits or concentrations, just walking around learning to identify which small rock (that sticks out from the environment like a sore thumb) corresponds to which of the 5 or so minerals you actually need, because you sure aren't going to be able to collect everything - inventory space is extremely limited early on. So you go out and hope that you randomly find the one you're looking for before you run out of oxygen. The sole exception was a particular one that I had to hunt around for, which was probably the most interesting thing I did during my playtime, punctuated by frustration when I realized that I needed a flashlight that I didn't have, so I had to make another tedious trip back to base, burning through my oxygen tanks the whole time.

Base building, normally my favorite part of these games, was even more lackluster. I had hoped for a feeling of setting up a complex logistics system on an alien world: laying power cables, fiddling with buttons and wires on panels, managing pressure and atmospheric gases, performing critical maintenance, growing food while on the verge of starving, sweating at the possibility of making a fatal mistake. Instead it's just a matter of unceremoniously plopping down devices that magically provide power, magically dig through rock with no byproducts, magically provide oxygen to your suit, and magically correct the mix of atmospheric gases to something breathable. Oh, and they all magically work forever, unless perhaps one happened to get hit with an odd meteorite - wouldn't know. One you've plopped your first set of magical devices, what do you have to look forward to? Gathering more minerals to plop another set of them, until you unlock the T2 version, and then plopping those down instead. And the scale of my operation barely felt like it would be enough to support myself, let alone make any changes whatsoever to the ecosystem of an entire planet. "Planet Wizard" might have been a more apt description here.

Graphically I didn't find the game to be up to modern standards. Textures are very flat and frequently don't blend well with whatever they're sitting near. The devices you put down lack a sense of character - that is, being a working machine. Wind turbines simply run at a constant speed forever. Solar panels are static and always clean. Drills barely move. Your own character only interacts with the environment via a tool that does everything. If the gameplay were more interesting it could easily make up for this, but such as it is, it's just another reason to be unenthused about the complete package.

Overall, I'd say that if you don't much care about the things I listed above and just think the idea of watching the planet turn from red to green and having life show up (again, magically) is cool, then by all means you may enjoy Planet Wizard- I mean Crafter. If you just like great survival/crafting games, though, the market is flooded with other titles that will respect your time and provide a more rewarding experience

As someone who've played this game 50+ hours in the Prologue and 300+ hours in Early Access since January, 2022, I can say I've been closely following the development of The Planet Crafter. It started out as the love project of two very committed developers. They created a small game with great promises and prospects for the future, and they really delivered above expectations in some aspects (while not in others, to tell you the truth). The colorful, rich and stylish design they worked with is remarkable, which continued to improve with later additions and the redesigning of some elements. It was a great journey to experience the newer and newer terraforming stages and features implemented in the game with the frequency of cca. 2-3 bigger updates/year according to a very clear roadmap.
Even though I never really wished for a multiplayer feature for this game, it was pretty obvious they were going in that direction, considering the huge number of players who simply won't play single player games and are begging for mp in every single new game that doesn't have that feature. IMO in this case it contradicts a fairly important lore element, which is not reconcilable with a MP setting, and some key parts of the story don't make much sense anymore when you're not alone on the planet. 
I mean, it's probably cool as the story is not complex or deep at all. This game is so much more about the massive freedom and variability of wholesome sandbox-type base design, building&crafting than anything else! I wouldn't even call it a survival game as this aspect is very simple and marginal. I remember my very first playthrough, when breathable atmosphere wasn't even a thing, that it took me like 40 hours until the first time I ever died, and even that was due to a fall. 
I'm gonna provide a brief pros&cons below to prevent this comment from becoming comparable to a novel in length. 

Pros:
- Beautiful visuals, unique world with various biomes.
- The environment changes a lot during the game, it's a great experience.
- Wholesome building, crafting, exploring (endless - as long as you want to continue). It's up to you to decide how your planet's biosphere will grow and what kind of creatures will populate it.
- Pretty big world (may not be true so much in multiplayer), with possible expansions in the future
- Massive and well thought-out automation is available in later stages of the game to prevent too much grind. This includes fast travel so your time is not wasted too much on pointless traveling. 
- Low level of difficulty and no hostilities at all. Focus is on setting your own goals and working to reach them. Then a bigger one. Then a bigger one. You can't lose what you've built by acts of God or any other forces of nature.
- Extremely nice and communicative developers who are very enthusiastically working on this project. They let players know what their plans are and they accomplish them. They gather a lot of feedback and input from players, there have been several QoL and balancing improvements.

- The game has very few buttons to press, which is fine, but it does mean that certain buttons are doing quite a bit, namely left click. [h1]Planet Crafter feels like an idle game with extra steps[/h1]

I want to like Planet Crafter, I really do, but Planet Crafter does not respect the player's time. Automation isn't unlocked until you're 20+ hours in. Almost all of my ~30 hour playtime has been walking resources from point A to point B or fiddling with my inventory. There are brief moments of levity when I get to do some base-building or get to walk somewhere [i]without[/i] needing to sprint as fast as possible to ferry items. And in those moments the game is genuinely enjoyable; the execution of watching terraforming happen in stages is gratifying and well done. Unfortunately, those bits are few and far between. Most of your time will be spent hauling a handful of items at a time on five-minute jaunts between your farms and hub.

I do like inventory management, when that mechanic [i]matters[/i]. Inventory management does not matter in Planet Crafter. At the time of writing there are no hostile mobs, and the environment is a non-threat. Time and danger are not constraining factors, so my "choice" to bring X or Y items don't impact my gameplay beyond drastically extending the time it takes to do anything [i]agnostic of my choices[/i] after the point where the atmosphere becomes breathable. 

This game desperately needs a beacon-type item that allows the player to build or craft using the inventory of any structure within the beacon's radius while the player is near that beacon. If Planet Crafter wants to utilize a logistics system, it should draw on the models of successful logistics titles like Factorio and Satisfactory. Those games give the player HUGE inventories because building the thing that makes you not have to move stuff around shouldn't require so much running around that you question the cost-effectiveness of building that system in the first place.

Food and water are needs that could be considered 'constraining factors,' but they're so trivial it would be an insult to put them in that taxonomy. Yes, your hunger and thirst bars drain quickly, but those resources are also easy to come by. The food/water mechanics feel like a waste of my time that breaks my immersion every ten minutes-- this is to say, they feel like Phantoms in Minecraft. This isn't a challenge, it's just annoying, and doubly so given most of this game at 30 hours has been ferrying resources. Food and water makes you have fewer inventory slots to ferry other items.

Tooltips are lacking. There's a lot of items that, when you unlock them, you'll have to search every machine to figure out which one crafts them and then just remember that bit of information. This is, IF you've even unlocked the thing you need to craft that item yet. The game is not good about only giving you items after you've unlocked prerequisites. The wiki is also pretty out of date, even on items released several updates ago.

There's also a bunch of machines that have variable outputs depending on which item you put in. E.G: Different species of butterfly make the butterfly spreader output more or fewer insects per second. This is well and good until you find or create a better species and then have to track down in the world, by memory, where that structure that needs changing is. Clumping a bunch of 'spreader' structures together tanks your framerate as these structures create a bunch of visual noise that's fantastic to look at, but creates performance issues in dense quantity. This gives the player conflicting incentives to space 'spreader' structures out for performance reasons, and to place them closer together so you don't have to do more tedious walking to find and replace obsolete parts.

It's cool, but there's way too much tedium. Playing Planet Crafter feels like playing an idle clicker game where you're performing the same numbing actions waiting for a number to go up in service of that brief moment when you can play the actual game. Until this game respects my time, it won't be enjoyable.

Because of automation being an option later in the game and a very forgiving oxygen system, you'll never have to pick up and move your whole base for convenience, meaning you can live in one spot for the entire game and never be massively inconvenienced. You can do that, but you don't have to. The last good bit I want to point out is the simplicity of everything. Many large-scale survival games fall into the trap of "You have to go here to get this thing, now you have to go there to get that thing, now you have to go all the way across the map to get that thing", while this game mitigates that impressively well. There is still a decent amount of travelling and exploring to be done, however the mandatory amounts are relatively small and don't make it feel as atrocious as some other games do. This is in large part thanks to the game's various speed upgrades making your run speed extremely fast by the game's end and thus making traversing the quite large world feel very quick and like a quick, in and out, 20 minute adventure.

Now's the point where I bring up the unfortunately large number of complaints with the game I have. As I said in the opening, I've been playing this game since early into early access, and I've seen it grow and evolve. However, not everything has grown and evolved in good ways. I'm going to have to break this up into a few sections because it's a long list.

The single biggest problem is the game's frame rate. My laptop can run Hearts of Iron IV and Minecraft at at minimum 60 FPS, however it struggles to get above 30 here quite often. Simply walking around trees is enough to tank the frame rate from the 60 I can get to around 20. Why this is the case, I don't know, but I blame poor optimisation.

Next biggest issue is the graphics. During EA when I got the game, my first thought was "Kinda simplistic and crappy UI, terrain looks kinda bad, but those are prolly just growing pains". Now I can say that they were unfortunately not growing pains. The UI isn't bad but it could be significantly better, and the terrain textures are still pretty ugly. I get that it's supposed to go from barren to lush, but the "lush" textures just look plain gross in many places. My other graphical complaint is the fog. When there's fog at all, your vision goes from infinite to near-sighted. You can't even see 2 feet in front of you.

Next up is the progression speed. In the early stages, you would gather resources and practically fly through terraformation goals. Closer to the end, however, it takes HOURS to make even a few percentage points of progress to the point that a friend of mine and I just left the game on while we watched YouTube because there was nothing left to do. I get that you can just place more machines and whatnot to speed it up, but that circles back around to the frame rate issues. Placing things just tanked the frame rate further, and I was already sick of the PowerPoint presentation. It doesn't help any that making larvae is the single most annoying thing in the game and yet they're vital to pretty much anything late-game.

Not as big but still a complaint is that the ground is still so unpolished and easy to break through that the devs left the F4 un-stuck button in the game in 1.0. You'd think they'd fix it up, maybe add some invisible walls so you can't just use the jetpack to completely break the game wide open, but no, you can still go literally anywhere if you wiggle with the jetpack in the right way, and you can just fall through the floor if you do the wrong thing in the wrong place. I didn't even know how F4 worked until I fell through the floor and got stuck inside a building. Had to use it to get out and now I can see just how abuse-able that button is. Shouldn't need to be in the game post-1.0.

Lastly, and I'm sad I have to say this, but the endings are awful. A few shots of the planet and some text on the screen just feels like a slap in the face to the 50+ hours I put into this save file (my other 10 were other files). I was so excited to finally see the ending to this game that I've loved for so long, but that was just... disappointing. They're all achieved in the same way but with very, very minor differences and just different text on the screen.

To conclude, I want to say that I love this game. I really do, flaws and all. I love it because it's the kind of game I always wanted to make. I always wanted to make a game where you survive on an alien planet and build up your base/the planet itself and eventually leave it. The whole experience was almost what I wanted, but its problems just sadden me to an honestly upsetting extent. I want to recommend this game so much more, but I just can't. I still do recommend it as it's a great time-sink and a very chill game for after a long day, but it's just too buggy and unpolished to recommend to just anyone.

TL;DR, game good but EXTREMELY flawed. Playable and enjoyable, but only to a specific niche.
GOOD:
          - Chill and relaxing
          - Simple and easy
          - Everything can be automated
BAD:
          - Terrible frame rate issues
          - Ugly and sometimes awful textures
          - Ungodly slow progression late-game
Verdict: Very flawed, but very enjoyable

Ok, so this game is an open world survival crafting basebuilding and terraforming game. It has online co-op and you can play solo. I've done both, and both are great, although it does seem that you progress a lot faster with co-op than alone, which could be seen as good or bad depending on how quickly you want to progress.

The game looks and sounds great, the controls all make sense and feel good. The most important thing in any game is a solid foundation of the basic stuff like visual appeal, sound design, and movement. They're all exceptional here. 

Beyond that basic foundation you've got quite an unique and compelling game here. I've seen a lot of people compare to subnautica and I get that, but I'd say that it's also so different from subnautica that the comparison isn't really that close once you get past the surface level of the two games. 

This is a game where exploration, crafting, base building, and looting take turns. You always have a bunch of stuff you can be doing, and yet you never feel like you've got anything you NEED to do. What I mean by that is that the game really lets you play it how you want to. You can focus on exploration and ignore everything else. You can focus on terraforming, or building and crafting. You will eventually have to do about equal parts of all of it, but the game doesn't force you to play it one way. Progress is locked by new technologies and sometimes by discovering locations in the world. Technologies are mostly locked by hitting certain terraforming goals like a certain amount of heat, pressure, oxygen, etc.

This game is big. This game is fun. This game doesn't hold your hand, but it does teach you what you need to know to enjoy it and do what you need to do in the game to progress. 

If you're considering playing for solo, go ahead. I have over 30 hours in solo and enjoyed every minute of it. It's more like playing subnautica in that you're all alone on a whole planet you need to discover. If you enjoy that idea, then you literally cannot do better than this game. There's nothing like it. I wish there was something like it because someday I'll want another game like this, but it stands alone, much like subnautica.

If you want to play co-op, I'd argue it's even more fun than solo, which is impressive considering just how fun the solo experience is in this game. That said, you will progress quite a bit faster co-op, and you may unlock a landslide of new tech in the first 4 hours or so of gameplay. It can get overwhelming, but luckily there are screens you can build to check and manage every single thing if the game if you want to, so it's just a matter of looking at a few screens at any given moment to know everything going on in the game, what you could be working on next, what's going to unlock soon, how the power is looking for your base, etc.

Anyway, so basically you explore, loot, build a base, and create new technologies. You have a clearly defined goal always for terraforming the mars-like planet you live on in the game. As you progress, you get to make bigger, more impressive, and more impactful changes on the planet. It just gets cooler and cooler as you play.

One thing people love about Subnautica is the sense of wonder and scope you feel on your first playthrough as you explore the alien world. Planet Crafter has a similar yet different vibe. You feel a sense of wonder and accomplishment from the way you CHANGE the world. In Subnautica, it's about exploration, survival, and the story. Just ask yourself if you're interested in the idea of transforming a dead planet into a living one, exploring it, and discovering...some things I won't mention because they would spoil both the story and the surprise but they're great. The way I would describe this game is "Idle Game meeds Survival Game".

What do I mean by that? Well, the game is basically separated into two parts: Idle and Exploration.

[h1]Idle[/h1]

The main goal of the game is "make numbers go up". There is no way around this: You want the numbers to go up (Pressure, Temperature and Oxygen in the beginning, other numbers later) and once you have set up the corresponding infrastructure, they keep going up in a steady rate. No need to insert coal into generators or anything like that. You build a thing that generates power, you build a thing that increases pressure - congratulations, now your pressure increases at a steady rate. The trick is that things keep getting unlocked. Let's say you generate 1 oxygen, pressure and temperature per second (don't worry about the units). Once you reach 100 oxygen, you now get a thing that generates 5 pressure/second! Cool, let's build that!
Then you reach 1000 pressure and you get a thing that generates 100 temperature/second. Build that and once you reach 5000 temperature you get a thing that generates 40 oxygen/second, once you reach 4000 oxygen you unlock the next pressure thing...and so on, and so on, round and round it goes. Exponential growth goes brrrrr.

The thing is - you need resources to actually BUILD those things. No resources ever get used up, you can always reclaim everything (well, everything that doesn't respawn anyways), but you NEED them to climb up the exponential ladder. For that you need...

[h1]Exploration[/h1]

A big part of the game is exploring the world and collecting the stuff you need to build up your base. And that part is very fun as well - the biomes change things up nicely, you keep finding stuff you did not expect and the best thing - while you are away, the numbers back at your base keep ticking up (there's that idle game component!). And as one expects you keep unlocking and building stuff that makes exploration easier (faster travel, more oxygen, more inventory space...).

What the game lacks (after the 6 hours I played so far) is automation. Playing it with friends is therefore recommended because that makes the game a lot easier for sure - if you enjoy exploring and bring back a lot of stuff your friend can use that to build up the power grid while you set up more plants to grow, for example. When exploring big crashed ships you halve the time you need to haul all that good loot back to base. And so on, and so on.

So, after about 8.5 hours of gameplay, I finally got to the "soft endgame" of the Early Alpha build - the Insect stage.
My impressions are sort of... mixed, and here's why.

The game on normal difficulty plays a lot like Subnautica on peaceful mode - no enemies, no real hazards aside from fall damage and occasional meteor showers, and I haven't died once to asphyxiation or thirst yet. It [b]also[/b] plays like Factorio or maybe Satisfactory, with how much you have to build and craft, but don't expect sprawling factories or massive mining plants - all the resources are literally lying around and you have to run and mine them No Man's Sky style.

Graphics are phenomenal, as is performance - I did not expect it to run on max settings with over 60 FPS on an RTX 2060 with so much foliage and water and whatnot. A lot of my idle time was spent just admiring the scenery and whizzing around the world on a jetpack.

Speaking of jetpack. This currently is [b]the only[/b] mode of transportation in the game with infinite fuel, and as soon as I got it, the game got massively easier. It also got me clipping into a lot of cliffs and weird places, which was also really fun :D I would prefer something like an electric buggy, with the jetpack running on biofuel or something for the sake of balance, but as it's Alpha, it's really not an issue.

What I really didn't like, and I hope the devs will fix in the future, is the bad use of scientific measurements as progress bars. Here's a TL;DR.

When you reach the (currently endgame) Insect stage (presumably when animal life starts to flourish), your planet has roughly 2 Pascals of atmospheric pressure, some 20 mK (0.02 K) of heat and 10 ppm of oxygen.
On their own, these numbers don't say anything, but here's what we have on Earth: 101325 Pascals of pressure, 293 K of temperature and 209460 ppm of oxygen.
Our planet literally has: [b]an atmosphere 50 thousand times less dense than Earth, close to absolute zero in temperature and oxygen content fit for a vacuum chamber somewhere in a lab[/b]. This is not livable, and makes absolutely zero sense when you look at it from a scientific perspective.

It also made me laugh a lot, when I saw grass and liquid water outside in what is essentially -273 C (-459.7 F) and no atmosphere to speak of.

Altogether, I recommend it. It's addictive, plays really well, and aside from that one flaw, is probably one of the better terraforming games out there. Worth a demo try or even a buy, if you're into it.

[i]TL:DR - For $20 you get about 40 hours of content in the game's current state. I think the price is fair for what you get, but sales are always nice. The game is a mixture between No Man's Sky and Subnautica. [b]Planet Crafter[/b] is relaxing with no enemies or threats (other than keeping water, food, oxygen up.) The end game needs more content, but the game is still a stand-out in the genre for its unique terraforming gameplay. I recommend it but I do have some issues with the game's pacing that I will point out below. *Review will be edited if a content update changes my opinion.*[/i]

The game is great and as you can see from the reviews, every one agrees. I played the game for just under 40 hours pretty consistently over the past few days and I really enjoyed it but I did get bored in the end-game. For this review I am not going to focus on typical things you see in a review like graphics, story, performance etc. Instead I want to talk about the pacing of the game because for me that is the biggest thing that can be improved upon by the developers. 

First a few nitpicks/notes (in-case a dev reads this):
- The game is open world, but not procedurally generated. This is not a problem, but it limits replayability. 
- The music is atmospheric and gets very repetitive quickly. It also does not match the game's tone and I ended up muting it and listening to other stuff. It would be nice to see the music change as the terraforming stages changed.
- There is much to explore, but travel in this game is a slog until you can build a teleporter or a T3 jetpack. 
- The art/graphics are mediocre compared to other similar games, but it gets the job done.
- If you launch two rockets in close succession, they crash and its hilarious.
- The rocks that the asteroids leave behind cause major issues and frustration. They need to vanish after a minute or so, or the players need a tool to remove them. Half the time you can't pick up the materials the asteroids leave behind because they get stuck under the rocks: especially the pulsar asteroids.
- In the late game you should not have to eat or drink as much as earlier stages. We need upgrades to reduce the tediousness of this process. 

Now on to the "pacing." What do I mean by pacing? Pacing to me is how well the game "flows" from start to mid-game, and then from the mid-game to the end-game content. In this game there are very distinct stages as the world terraforms and I want to talk about the flow or pacing from going to stage A then to B then to C etc. Note: There may be minor spoilers below.

[b]Early Game[/b]
The early game is great and easily the best part of the game. You gather resources, build machines and are excited when new stuff unlocks. You don't want to explore too far yet because oxygen gets consumed very rapidly and there is plenty to build at your base anyways. When you start to see that hint of a blue sky developing, it is a very rewarding feeling. You start to settle in with upgraded gear and many second tier machines. Much of your terraforming kicks into auto pilot for a bit and you can start to explore the world. Your biggest hurdle at this stage is finding and harvesting aluminum which is pretty scarce and getting a super alloy is like a special treasure. You also have to keep the power going and the tier 2 solar panels are pretty pricey. That said, I think the way the game flows at the start is great "pacing" for a survival game as you should have to work to keep making progress.

[b]Mid Game[/b]
The ice begins to melt and you can start to explore more areas. You find more materials and in certain spots you can get an ore extractor going. By the mid-game the game becomes much easier and you're not starving for things like aluminium, slufur or irridium. You also can launch rockets into space to give you terraformation % boosts at this time and asteroids will fall with materials for you to gather as well. Creating heat and power is a priority as you start to plant grass and flowers around the land. Exploration is easier now and you will find many secret locations, chests, bunkers and all of these places have loot boxes with very high end materials. Transporting everything back and fourth is tedious and a big critique I have of the game at this phase is there is no vehicle. You get a jetpack, but it is not much faster than walking to be honest and I really wish a teleporter was unlocked in this phase. (By the time one unlocks it almost feels like it is not needed anymore.) The game starts to slow down as you come out of the mid game, but the end game is when it really stalls. 
***If a dev reads this: The rocks the asteroids leave behind are too huge and annoying to deal with. They need to vanish quickly so we can harvest what they leave behind. I had a rock block my door and it sucks to have to reload the game to get rid of it.

[b]End Game[/b]
By the end game you are waiting for your terraforming numbers to climb, but they do so at a snail's pace. At this point you have access to literally every material. You can mine everything, asteroids dropping materials happen all the time, your farms are going and providing food, and if you've been thoughtful about your base building it will run like a Swiss watch. The problem I have with this phase in the game is you don't get many things unlocked anymore. At this phase you are very self reliant: your base is working, all your machines are going, food and water are no longer sparse, and every thing is just on "auto pilot." I found myself sitting AFK for awhile and watching YouTube because I was getting bored watching terraforming numbers with no unlocks happening. In my opinion, one can only base build for so long - and sure, I can keep building more machines to keep pumping the numbers up, but that game play loops gets pretty stale. That is how I started to feel about the game in the end: I was getting bored. And I don't think more content beyond the oxygen phase will fix this issue. The issue is not content, the issue is the pacing of the game.

So how do the devs improve this? I think the timelines between terraforming stages need to be compressed with more machines/content for late game to keep us occupied. I also think some of the crafting patterns could be more complex or take more time to gather/create the materials. Resources are beyond abundant and there is nothing the player has to "work" for. This way players work a little harder, but not for as long and the payoff will be quicker. I don't think "rushing" is the plan here, but we just need more to do so the process can speed up a little. Satisfactory is a great example of a game that has great pacing all the way through from point A to point Z.

In conclusion it is a great game that you should play if you like this genre. For a small indie dev studio, this game is a massive achievement. It plays super well, not many bugs, and it is relaxing. Again, for me the issue is pacing. I know more content will come and that is great, however I think it takes too long to get from point A to B in this game and then B to C is way longer with not much to do in-between. Sure you can explore, base build and make more of the same machines over and over, but it just gets stale after a bit.

Regardless, I still recommend this title and I will be returning to it when more content drops.

I do want to underline the fact that in order to progress and in order to knock off each achievement or ultimately, finish the game - you will be manually crafting A LOT. And I mean A LOT. So if that isn't your thing, I wouldn't play this game. I have played No Man's Sky, both Subnautica games and Minecraft to death and this game has much more crafting than any of them IMO.

You find yourself on a barren planet with no life and just a few basic materials to hand. You are limited with what you can build or upgrade at the start and will progress towards terraforming the planet into a breathable, lush green paradise with water, trees and life. For the first 10 hours, you will be focusing on base building, crafting and upgrading your gear and machines in order to slowly progress through the terraforming stages of the planet. 

This can be enjoyable, it really depends on you and your imagination. As you advance your machines and progress with upgrades and unlocks of certain rarer elements, the terraforming process speeds up and you will start unlocking stages quicker than at the start of the game. 

One of the main drawbacks in my opinion is that there is some really good, fun and enjoyable machines which you unlock very deep into the game which I think should be available much earlier on. As an example, you will eventually unlock what could be full automation using things such as drones and auto-crafters. If you build the base efficiently and in a good location, you could essentially automate your entire operation properly. That would be really cool to watch and will allow you to explore more and focus on other things such as making a brilliant base. But by the time you get to the stage which allows this level of automation, it's end game. There is nothing else left for you to do.

As a suggestion to the developers, I think that the teleporter and the drones should be unlockable considerably earlier on in the game and require less rare materials. It would make building more enjoyable and will move things along nicely at a better pace. 

With that main drawback aside, I think the gameplay progresses at a reasonably fair pace. It would be great to see some more areas to explore in the future and i would happily play the game again. In fact, I am likely going to start over again and play on the hardest mode now I have all the achievements done and I know how the game works. 

The other minor issues are snapping could be better when building, there could be a little more variety in parts and the rotation of objects could be more free-flowing as opposed to rotating to specific angles.

For the achievement hunters it is a dead simple one. You just need patience. 

PRO TIPS (SPOILERS)

Build your starting base in the middle of the map. There is a pod which you start at on normal mode. If you look out of the pod and look for a rock formation towards the centre, there is an open area there which is slightly raised above your current level. Build here as you will need to be above water as you progress and your starting pod will be about 20 feet underwater in a lake.

Build your base 2 or 3 ladders high off of the ground. The reason to do this, is as you progress and you get access to autocrafters, you can build many things under your base which produce food (farms) or honey (beehives) as well as gas, algae (if your base is built slightly over hanging water) and many elements. With a room in your base with lockers stored full of goodies as well as drones on the roof of your base constantly supplying materials, 2 or 3 autocrafters set up in certain segments and radius's in your base can make your life a lot easier. 

You don't need to build rooms or living spaces to place lockers or autocrafters inside. You can just place the foundations down which cost 1 iron and place anything you want on top of them. This will be useful for when you are forced to build miners in specific places away from your base which have materials that are needed and only found in certain areas. 

Make and use plenty of rockets to really speed things up. Each rocket type gives a boost of 1000% (10 times) to whatever your current pressure, heat etc is and the effect is planet-wide. This starts getting diminishing returns after about 10 rockets of each type is launched, but very worth it even after that amount. They are key to progression speed, particularly mid-game. 

Always have plenty of water, food and oxygen to hand. 

When out exploring wrecks, containers and other things, always take the stuff you can't make such as flower or food seeds. And anything else which would be costly or limited for you to build at that point in time. Do not be tempted to take minerals and other materials unless you really do need them as you will have plenty of all materials as you progress. 

Be patient and enjoy the game. It is worth the money and puts a lot of bigger budget and AAA games to shame.

- Explore the map to find resources you need for these
- Eventually see results of your "Terraforming"
